Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Integrating Logic Based Declarative Programming Paradigms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is developing a new, powerful paradigm for declarative programming, capable of solving computational problems that require a large amount of diverse knowledge and use of different reasoning methods. Such problems frequently occur in practice but cannot be solved by more traditional methods of declarative (or procedural) programming. The research includes the development of a language for representing various types of knowledge, algorithms and systems for reasoning about this knowledge, and a methodology of using the language and the systems for solving a large variety of computational problems. Our approach to declarative programming will integrate the ideas from Answer Set Programming (ASP), Constraint Programming (CP), programming methods based on Boolean Satisfiability (SAT) and Satisfiability Modulo Theory (SMT), and with a longer-term goal of including abductive and probabilistic reasoning as well. The approach will be tested on problems in challenging application domains such as a decision support system for space shuttle controllers, secure software systems with complex authorization and obligation policies, and systems capable of planning and scheduling based on non-trivial domain knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The needs of automated reasoning with knowledge is ubiquitous in software applications from  managing operations in an organization to supporting clinical decisions for patient centered care. In the last several decades, declarative programming has demonstrated its potential to meet the needs. However, these applications usually require a large amount of diverse knowledge and use of different reasoning methods, posing a challenge to the state of the art declarative programming. In this project, we further developed the declarative programming paradigm (DPP). Particularly, we have extended Answer Set Pogramming (ASP) -- one of the dominating DPPs -- with different constructs to enable its ability to address the representation and reasoning with different types of knowledge. Particularly, we have extended ASP to represent and reason with constraint and uncertain knowledge. We also extended ASP with constructs such as functions, aggregates and modal operators to support more natural and easy representation of practical problems. Based on the ASP systems developed, we have developed methodology and solutions for a range of challenging problems. Firstly, we have developed action languages that facilitate the representation and reasoning withdynamic systems which are the base underlying many intelligent systems. Secondly, we developed a novel and very promising solution to the challenging problem of automatically making recommendations according to clinical practice guidelines and patient conditions. Thirdly, we developed a general solution for the difficult temporally expressive planning problems. Fourthly, we demonstrated that ASP based tools have been very effective in helping mine opinions from a large amount of product reviews from customers. Fifthly, we have developed an architecture for intelligent agents such as Robots. Finally, we have developed a method for generatingtutorials automatically from AutoCAD drawings. 
There is a potential for the results produced in this research to influence our daily life. Here are some examples. Patient centered care will provide care that is respectful of and responsive to individual patient preferences, needs, and values, and ensure that patient values guide all clinical decisions. The result obtained from this project shows a feasible solution on how clinical practice guidelines can be used in patient centered care. As for another example, Robots are expected to address a lot of problems in our society. However, the current robots are still far from "intelligent" when interacting with humans and their environment. Our architecture for intelligent agents is expected to equip a robot with new level of intelligence when interacting with its environment. We are currently working with researchers from China to exploit the opportunities for making more intelligent robots. 
Several PhD students and undergraduate students have been trained through this project. One undergraduate continued his study as a graduate student. Two PhD studentsare women and two undergraduate students are from underrepresented minorities. We have been offering undergraduate and graduate courses based on DPP since the start of this project. We have taught ASP to students from New Deal High School and from TexPREP -- a progam to prepare middle and high school students to major in STEM in college. Our research results have been published in major Artificial Intelligence and Logic Programming conferences, and they are accessible from the website of our lab.
